title: How many confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. will be reported for the week ending 27 March 2021?
preds: Already 374031 cases this week - the increase is surprising, I was wrong like most others here assuming it would be less than 400k. Shared defeat ;-)

I had been certain we'd see 300k to 400k cases, but instead, we're seeing a slight uptick in cases. 5 days into the forecast and we're already at 294.8k. We only have Friday and Saturday left, and they'd have to average 52.6k to keep cases under 300k. Sundays are low reporting days, and we already had our Sunday. Saturdays tend to be a bit lower than the preceding days of the week. But no Fri/Sat average has been under 52.6k for a very long time. Last week, at the recent minimum, the Fri/Sat average was ~54k. So, it seems extremely unlikely to me that today and tomorrow are going to come in lower than 52.6k, based on recent history. I think the total cases for the week is almost certainly going to be 400k to 500k.
410k weekly cases with 2 days left, seems more likely to remain above 400k.
Final estimate. Increasingly feel that P( good admin | previously bad admin) is an encapsulation of the modern world.

changing 100% to 400k
already 293347 new cases since March 20 
if  in sum > 106653 for last two days, we will pass 400k
Last 7 days went just over 400K.  Too close to call now.
7-day rolling mean ~ 58,000. Trend flattened after dropping for a few weeks. Difficult to say whether under 400k or above, but slight edge for landing over 400k

Today, the numbers on Github jumped to 86903, kinda confusing
> Already 225k this week
> only ~60k / day until March 27 and we hit 400k
Covid rates are going up in some places due to it being spring break for many colleges, but I have no reason to believe that there is going to be a massive US-wide outbreak this coming week.
Based on @Ryan-Beck's research, I'll go with the theory that the blip was a one-time thing.  But I'll increase the chances that the final answer is 400-500k.

The recent dump of cases in new york should get spread out, but we can't be confident of how many extra cases will follow AND be placed in the relevant time window. There is some buffer, hence the 70:30. But as ever with a value close to a boundary as a deadline rapidly approaches, this cannot be guaranteed.
See @Ryan-Beck (25/03/21 12:28 GMT) for links and explanation.

Figured out that most of the bump today is coming from New York. However, even without the one day dump of 20k cases from New York new cases would be up. I think it's a coin-flip whether these cases get backdated before the question is resolved (or at all), and a coin-flip whether cases come down enough over the next couple days to drop it below 400k cases. Also possible New York hasn't worked out all its problems yet and may have more cases to dump tomorrow. However, it looks like from the source data and from the NYT page for New York that these cases were from the last week or so, so that seems to me to indicate that cases should have been gradually climbing to where they are now, but instead just jumped there all at once. So it seems a bit more likely to me that cases hold steady above 400k or climb very slowly from here. New York's cases, see the description farther down the page about the data disruption and large increase today: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/new-york-coronavirus-cases.html Weekly cases: https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=398..428&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=Weekly&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~USA Google sheet with the latest JHU data: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/148Ds_eNz-TyOwXuPctjooOldHXpH-0F_JqY4ywdiuVo/edit?usp=sharing
With 215K cases this week and 2 days to go.  It is pretty safe to say that the total number will be between 300K and 400K.
Need to look into what this huge jump was today, possibly something that could get backdated later.

Forces pushing cases up: B.1.1.7 variant, communities opening up.
B.1.1.7 is about to become dominant in the US. In countries where it has become dominant, cases ceased declines and typically turned upward. In Michigan, on the leading edge of B.1.1.7 dominance in the US, cases/day have ticked up in the past couple weeks (see, e.g., https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1374187165932871680). Forces pushing cases down: seasonality, and cumulative immunity due to previous infections and vaccination.
Good weather is finally kicking in.
~35% of the country has had Covid and has largely effective immunity to currently circulating strains.
~25% has had at least one vaccine dose.
~14% has been fully vaccinated; the most recent ones won't have full protection this week yet, though.
So ~45% of the population has ~90% immunity, another ~15% maybe 50% to 75% immunity. Cases in the US have nearly plateaued.
Will B.1.1.7 and poor behavior win out, or will warm spring weather and immunity win out?
My best guess is that we'll continue to see a more or less flat curve for this week, with the beginning of an uptick by the end of the week as B.1.1.7 becomes dominant in more places, in line with Michigan but tempered by weather.
Project an average of 54.8k to 55.3k cases/day for the week => 384k to 387k cases for the week.
Some chance of a bit more of an uptick starting to happen this week, so I'll give the 400k to 500k category a 5% chance, perhaps to be updated to a higher level later this week.
What are the latest nr’s from John hopkins? I can’t open them,too much hassle, just use worldometers and others...  but I think my forecasts are nor correct then as nr’s have (big?) differences?

Checked in on the numbers and we are averaging 50,447 over the past 7 days meaning the expected continued average is 353,129 if nothing changed. The week-over-week change was -198 per day so we have definitely hit a trough and it is so unlikely that we drop to 40,000 per day as to be 0%. I still maintain a 2% chance that it is more than 400,000 in case things skyrocket but we would need an additional 6,695 cases per day over this week in order to reach that. There is a single day in the past week with only 35,370 cases so I adjusted the 2% chance to a 4% chance because this reporting day is not always so small (additional 14,000 case jump easily).
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailytrendscases Daily rate appears to have stabilized around 50,000/day
Possibly weekly numbers will start coming down, but not until end of spring break, Easter...

Source: https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#forecasting_weeklycases
- week ending 13 March= 412,103
- week ending 6 March=470,232 The number of cases and deaths is decreasing and there is no reason for them to increase again (vaccines, season) If -58,129/week during 2 weeks=>295,845
But the slope of new cases has decreased very drastically between these 2 weeks, it is possible that it decreases less quickly (regression to the mean)

Point estimate 329,000. Weekly decline over last 4 weeks averages to 11.8% per week. Straight projection from week ending yesterday would take us just under 300,000. Downward pressure on that number: more vaccinations, warming weather. Upward pressure: spring break socializing, Texas and other states dropping mask mandates, new more contagious variants of virus, CDC ensemble models do not go under 300,000 for next 4 weeks.

The rates of COVID Infection as tracked by the CDC are projected to be right smack between 300-400K. The vaccination rates are increasing and even with college kids traveling for "spring break" or a variant going wild, it consistently has taken 3 weeks before behavioral changes impact the trajectory of the data. Two weeks out, the data is pretty predictable with COVID.
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#forecasting_weeklydeaths

The total reported cases for the past 7 days (March 7-13) is 467,839 or an average of 66,834 cases/day. (https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html). Although I do see this number trending down with increasing vaccine rates, the lifted restrictions in parts of the U.S. and mutations make me hesitant to include a lower bin.
7-day moving average 54373. *7=381K (bin 4), trend still slightly down
7-day average is about 62,000. This would put a week's worth of cases at about 434,000. However, cases continue to decrease.

Giving up my previous pessimistic position...
@OH

Hard to read how this will unfold. Is there any reason why cases should drop rapidly from here? I don't see any news about new and/or increased restrictions.
The main forecasts are now concerned with the winter (https://edition.cnn.com/2021/03/12/health/us-coronavirus-friday/index.html), suggesting that this current wave will continue to fizzle out. I have 300,000 - 400,000 as roughly twice as likely as the bin below because it will need a linear or accelerated drop in cases. Far from impossible especially with the noise about these figures.

7-day moving average 56599. *7=396K (bin 4), trend down.
No reason, why it should go up significantly. Vaccine and weather should lead to a further decrease or at least flattening.

Correcting myself: If the decrease continues in a linear way - which we don't know, it might also go up again because of lightened restrictions (e.g. Texas) and mutations with higher reproduction number - we would reach 285k, so I give 20% to < 300k, 80% to 300-400k; guess this will remain suspenseful btw. 200-300 and 300-400 and need updates every other day.

Threshold for 300k is 42k per day.  Still above 50k per day which give us 350k.
Still expect some increase by end month, but will be netted off by deceases elsewhere.  Think it will be close around the 50k per day mark, hence 350k ish. I like the graphics on the NPR website.  The hexagons give a feel of how raté of transmission goes and the table at the bottom which is updated on a rolling basis shows trends over recent weeks by state.  They all bee green/decreasing recently, but now there are yellows/steady showing up, so guess some will go amber/increasing soo.  Need to keep an eye on it but expect the daily average to properly flatten and maybe tick up.
https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2020/09/01/816707182/map-tracking-the-spread-of-the-coronavirus-in-the-u-s?t=1615593763219 Keeping and eye out but it’s only 2 or so weeks to go, so don’t think there’s time for the decrease to turn into a precipitous rise in that time to get us back over the 400k mark.

-Thinking the current trends will continue, with slight weighting toward downward numbers given increase in vaccinations - teachers, others in childcare, etc., now receiving priority as well
-Possible uptick in spring break travel, but will people away that week choose to get tested if feeling unwell or hold off till they get back home? So possibly cancels out with fewer tests
No new signs of the rate to drop faster than it is doing.
Short term forecast, but looks good for a steady decrease.

Currently just shy of 400k/week, and trending down slowly Most likely it will continue to drop, but won't get below the 300k number Vaccine roll-out battling against states re-opening.  Could begin to see a re-opening mini-surge

Threshold for 300k is 42k per day.  Still above 50k per day which give us 350k.
Still expect some increase by end month, but will be netted off by deceases elsewhere.  Think it will be close around the 50k per day mark, hence 350k ish.
We’re at 385K per week on Worldometers. They report a few more than the official site. Case rate is falling, so midpoint is right around 350,000.
Still more than 50,000 seven day average, or 350,000 a week. Changing forecast to reflect lower number.
Forecasting within 50K of 385,000 as case rate reduces more slowly or flattens over next two weeks, due to some easing of restrictions, St Patricks day and staggered Spring breaks

Source
Overall declining trend. there is a weekly pattern for testing - predict 33,000/day average https://covid19.healthdata.org/united-states-of-america?view=infections-testing&tab=trend&test=positive_tests

7-day moving average 58564. *7= 410K (only just bin 5), trend down. 
No reason, why it should go up significantly. Vaccine and weather should lead to a further decrease or at least flattening.
The CDC forecasts that in 2 weeks COVID cases in the U.S will be around 377, 877. https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#forecasting_weeklycases
Cases over the past two days are running less than 350,000 per week.  Could keep falling--or there could be a surge due to variants and lessening of restrictions.
Threshold for 400k is 57k per day.  Current rate about 60k, likely to drop but still risk of case increase by end March due to ease of restrictions.
Adjusting upward to compensate for a lower than anticipated reduction in cases.

The case counts for the last 3 weeks have remained steady.  There have been between 430K-480K new cases per week.  With more individuals getting vaccinated, this number is expected to decrease slightly.  But at the same time states are opening back up, which could offset any gains seen by the vaccines.

It could vary significantly, but I expect it to drop in the USA as temps rise and people go out more.  Loosening restrictions could push it the other way though.   I believe the current level is about 430k/wk.

For the past seven days (02/27-03/05), the total cases are 428,892. With states reopening and spring break also at that time, I believe that the total cases will continue to stay in the 400k-500k range.

Updated my numbers based on Spring Break and potential increase in infections. Reduced likelihood that we will decrease below 300,000 and increased chance that we could pop above 400,000. I believe a week or two post 3/27 will be much higher chances of 400,000+

Looking at the data for the past week (3/4 minus 2/25) we get 384,809 cases. These numbers have been falling across the US, but now states are reopening. The question is - how quickly will we see the effects of current policy? The answer is - at least a 2 week delay if the COVID incubation period has remained the same as it was previously. That means that policy enacted on 3/3/21 will show its effects on 3/17/21 and therefore will likely be considered as part of this. Overall, we are trending downward on the daily averages (simple daily averages over past 4 weeks are 88480, 63798, 61464, and 54972) and we will likely continue to see this decrease through 3/17 at least. I highly doubt that removal of mask mandates in 2 states will make a significant difference in people's behavior at this time because people are settled in their ways. The change in policy may cause people to hang out in more dangerous situations, though and could fuel a slight increase in transmission. Assuming the 8826 decrease in cases per day over the past 2 weeks is a relatively safe assumption, we are looking at expected value around 46,146 cases per day as of 3/19. Fairly reasonable and potentially on the low side. Given that rate over the course of 7 days means we are still pushing 323,000 cases around that time. It's a large stretch to get to 400,000 from there and less of a stretch (but more-so behaviorally) to get to 300,000.

States like Connecticut and Texas are opening and releasing all restrictions. 
NYC is opening movie theatres and event venues (33% capacity). Spring break runs from March 9th to April 21st. The two peak weeks will be the week of March 7-14. Holy Week is March 28 to April 3. 
Vaccinations continue to increase nationwide. In places like NYC, health dept. announced it will have enough vaccines to offer everyone by the end of April and vaccination sites are now running around the clock. Using a 50K daily cases base for now.
used wrong data (hospitalizations instead of number of cases. correcting.
Amended forecast 425,000-525,000 allowing for staggered Spring breaks and some easing of restrictions
* Based on extrapolating the seasonal respiratory disease pattern.

With the rate of decline slowing, and reviewing data from the previous two waves, it looks as if numbers will continue to drop but at a much slower rate than immediately after the peak. 
I currently forecast 380,000-480,000 but will reduce the range every few days.

Current average daily rate is 65k or 450k per week and dropping slightly.  Putting outer bounds of 350k to 500k for now. By end of month COVID restrictions lifted in Texas will have an impact, offsetting the current decrease a bit.  Hence think figures will plateau a bit.
Correcting previous forecast. Forgot to multiply by 7. Currently about 450. Basic trend is down, probably not fast enough to reach 30000.  Could get a spike due to reopenings.
The last time we saw cases in excess of 100000 was early January. We’re closer to 50,000 now, and it takes a few weeks for cases to increase by almost a factor of two. Very unlikely.

According to the CDC report,
5 days ago — The current 7-day average is 66,348 cases, a 73.4% decline. ... the 74,806 cases reported on February 24 remains much higher ...
Today the ninth of March the case number is around 190,000...
The number of new cases is 448,000 for the last 7 days (March 3).
I'll start with a projected rate of decrease of 2.5% per day for new case numbers.  That puts us around 250k/week on March 27.

Can’t access data on my ipad, but CDC shows a rolling average of 66,000 per day the last seven days, or 462,000.  Looking at circumstances, we have vaccinations as a positive, driving numbers down, along with those who have already been vaccinated or had CoVid. The spring/summer “break” has also hit.  So even with the negatives (loosening restrictions and variants) I do not foresee a huge surge.  I am putting the 462,000 as a top number with the assumption that the pros outweigh the cons and the number will go down.

Too soon for vaccines to really be driving cases into the ground, though I do think they'll help keep things low. So many possible factors like seasonality, adherence to masking and best practices, a drop after a holiday spike, herd immunity from the recent spike, and vaccinations among healthcare workers at play. My guess for right now is just that we're leveling out a bit at somewhere around 475k weekly cases, and I would guess it's possible it could slowly decrease farther, but the last two dips downward bottomed out at 140k and 240k weekly cases, and I don't think we'll reach that point yet, it'll take more vaccinations to make that happen. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~USA&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=weekly&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=location&pickerSort=asc
